items.title: Leveraging tax credits and incentives for sustainability projects

ai.summary: Based on the available descriptionâ€¦ Randa Barsoum of PwC US emphasizes that energy incentives are only one part of sustainability-related tax opportunities, highlighting state and local abatements, location-based incentives, and R&D tax credits tied to innovation like reimagining packaging or processes. The key message: viewing sustainability investments through a broader tax lens can unlock meaningful tax value.
bullets: Energy tax credits are important but not the whole picture.
State and local abatements can support sustainability initiatives.
Location-based incentives may influence project siting and economics.
R&D tax credits can apply to innovation efforts (e.g., reimagining processes).
Broader tax planning can reveal meaningful value from sustainability investments.
takeaways: Donâ€™t limit incentives analysis to energy creditsâ€”evaluate state and local abatements as part of project economics.
Factor location-based incentives into site selection and cost models for new builds or expansions.
Consider whether innovation in processes qualifies for R&D tax credits when planning efficiency or sustainability upgrades.
Adopt a broader tax lens on sustainability investments to uncover additional tax value that can affect capital and operational decisions.

items.title: Bringing In $251K A Year With 3 Jobs In The Bay Area

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Naseema McElroy, a 44-year-old labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, California, brings in $251K a year across three jobs and runs a personal finance brand called Financially Intentional. She accumulated nearly $1 million in debt by 2015, documented her debt-payoff journey publicly, and was debt-free by 2017.
bullets: Naseema McElroy is a 44-year-old labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, CA.
Title states she earns $251K per year by working three jobs.
She started the personal finance brand Financially Intentional to document paying off debt.
By 2015 she had nearly $1 million in debt and became debt-free by 2017.
This profile is part of CNBC Make It's Millennial Money series.
takeaways: High-earning Bay Area workers may combine multiple jobs and side businessesâ€”consider flexible scheduling and policies that accommodate nontraditional work arrangements.
Employees who have navigated large debt burdens may value employer financial-wellness benefits and education programs.
In markets with entrepreneurial employees, offering support for side businesses or flexible hours can help attract and retain talent.
Communications about benefits and work flexibility should acknowledge diverse income strategies employees may pursue.
